claim.text: Combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12%
claim.exact_quote: combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings not only improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12%

evidence.evidence_text: Combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12%
evidence.limitations: The study acknowledges gender bias due to the imbalance in gender ratio of speakers and demographic bias given that companies are from the public stock market of the United States, which may not generalize directly to non-native speakers.
evidence.exact_quote: combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12%

evidence.evidence_text: Utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not significantly deteriorate model performance
evidence.limitations: The evidence is based on an ablation analysis of the M3A model across different modalities for the SOTA M3A model, and the success may vary with different data or models.
evidence.exact_quote: utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not significantly deteriorate model performance

conclusion.limitations: Lacks comparative analysis with other data combination methods

claim.text: Reduces gender bias caused due to audio-based neural networks by over 30%
claim.exact_quote: also reduces gender bias caused due to audio-based neural networks by over 30%

evidence.evidence_text: Combining tabular data with text transcripts and audio recordings reduces gender bias caused due to audio-based neural networks by over 30%
evidence.limitations: The assessment of gender bias reduction specifically isolates the improvement to the integration of tabular data, but does not explore the interplay between all data types in depth.
evidence.exact_quote: combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings not only improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% but also reduces gender bias caused due to audio-based neural networks by over 30%

conclusion.limitations: Does not specify the types of gender biases addressed

claim.text: Utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not significantly deteriorate model performance
claim.exact_quote: utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not significantly deteriorate model performance

evidence.evidence_text: Substituting company filings for its audio counterpart, in conjunction with text transcripts, does not significantly deteriorate model performance
evidence.limitations: This evidence is derived from the ablation study's comparative performance metrics, which may rely on the specific data sets and model architecture used.
evidence.exact_quote: substituting company filings instead of its audio counterpart inconjunction with text transcripts does not significantly deteriorate model performance

conclusion.limitations: Does not explore if improvement could be achieved with better audio processing techniques

claim.text: Replacing audio clips with tabular data from company filings leads to a reduction of data processing time and data storage requirements by over 90% and 50%, respectively
claim.exact_quote: Replacing audio clips with tabular data from company filings leads to a reduction of data processing time and data storage requirements by over 90% and 50%

evidence.evidence_text: Replacing audio clips with tabular data from company filings leads to a reduction of data processing time and data storage requirements by over 90% and 50%, respectively
evidence.limitations: This claim is primarily based on the inherent differences in processing and storage requirements between audio and tabular data, without explicit detail on the computational or storage metrics.
evidence.exact_quote: Replacing audio clips with tabular data from company filings leads to a reduction of data processing time and data storage requirements by over 90% and 50%

conclusion.limitations: Assumes linear scalability and does not account for potential trade-offs in data granularity or quality
